channel.title: CNN.com - World
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - World
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: $40 helps family break free of abuse
item.description: Johanna Crawford was volunteering for a domestic violence shelter in 2003 when she answered a hot line call she will never forget.

item.title: Know a hero? Nominate them!
item.description: Do you know an everyday person changing the world? It's easy to nominate them as a CNN Hero.

item.title: 'Kliptown' kids reclaim their future
item.description: Brian Munyai has spent nearly all of his 22 years living in a one-room shack that has never had electricity or running water.

item.title: After tragic visit, officer says 'enough'
item.description: Shortly after joining the Lake Mary Police Department in 2007, Zach Hudson was dispatched to the home of two elderly women.

item.title: An answer to grannies' cries for help
item.description: Jackson Kaguri escaped poverty, earned a college degree and was living the American dream. But when he went back to his old village in Uganda, he realized he had to do something.

item.title: Dad gives teens money not to drink
item.description: Five years ago, Leo McCarthy lost his 14-year-old daughter, Mariah, when a drunken driver hit her and two of her friends as they walked down a sidewalk near her home. But he refused to let her tragic death become just another statistic.

item.title: War vets find peace at end of leash
item.description: A trip to the grocery store used to send James McQuoid into a panic. When the Iraq War veteran heard a child crying, he would remember kids screaming in Fallujah. But things are getting better now that he has Iggie by his side.

item.title: Beijing flood death toll doubles
item.description: Chinese authorities have more than doubled the official death toll from last weekend's flooding that swamped highways, homes and farms across the capital.

item.title: Intel: Kim wed in 2009
item.description: North Korean supreme leader Kim Jong Un married 23-year-old Ri Sol Ju in 2009, according to a South Korean lawmaker on Thursday.

item.title: Bo Xilai's wife charged with murder
item.description: The wife of controversial Chinese politician Bo Xilai has been formally charged with murder, the state-run Xinhua news agency said Thursday.

item.title: '$1T' fuel subsidies sparks debate
item.description: Political consensus was hard to find at last month's Rio +20 Earth Summit but there was at least one group speaking with unity on the planet's environmental and economic future.

item.title: Has the electric car found its range?
item.description: Despite their green credentials, electric cars still come up short against their petrol-powered cousins when it comes to range -- how far they go before the battery needs recharging.

item.title: 'Crate home' thinks outside the box
item.description: Living in a house made from shipping containers isn't exactly everyone's idea of a dream home.

item.title: Noah's Ark replica
item.description: A Dutchman has built a replica of Noah's Ark to biblical proportions, following a dream his homeland would be flooded.

item.title: Japan grapples with teen bullies
item.description: Incense burns in the corner of the Nakai family living room -- part of an altar to their daughter Yumi, who committed suicide seven years ago. Yumi was just 12 years old when she took her own life, jumping from a condominium building.

item.title: Olympics: Medals, money and more
item.description: As the 2012 Summer Games begin, check out the medals, the money and which four nations have competed in every Summer Olympics.

item.title: London in time-lapse
item.description: Watch a time lapse film of how a run-down area was transformed into an Olympic arena ahead of the grand opening ceremony.

item.title: Spa offers 'snake massage'
item.description: A Moscow spa uses snakes as part of its exotic massage service.

item.title: Kim Jong Un, wife at amusement park
item.description: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and his wife take in attractions at a local amusement park. State media reports.

item.title: Horror inside Mali refugee camp
item.description: CNN's Erin Burnett goes inside a refugee camp in Mali which houses people who have fled Islamic militants.

item.title: Dramatic rescue of wedding party
item.description: A wedding caravan fell 30 feet into a river after a bridge collapsed in China.

item.title: America and its gun history
item.description: What is it about Americans and guns?

item.title: Africa's 'bombs and bullets' myth
item.description: Africa is poor, corrupt and rural. Right? Think again. A team of young documentary makers is hoping to burst the myth of Africa as a dangerous backwater by shining a light on some inspiring projects taking place on the continent.

item.title: U.S. sending cows to Kazakhstan
item.description: Kazakhstan is building a new industry in cattle farming with outside help. CNN's Frederik Pleitgen reports.

item.title: Norway massacre, 1 year later
item.description: A year after Anders Behring Breivik killed 77 people in a bomb and gun rampage in Norway, Prime Minister Jens Stoltenberg urged Norwegians to "honor the dead by celebrating life."

item.title: First Bollywood superstar dies
item.description: The Indian actor Rajesh Khanna, who became the first Bollywood superstar, died Wednesday in Mumbai at the age of 69, his family said.

item.title: From Arab Spring to Olympics
item.description: Before the light, the dark.

item.title: Canine cops to carry cameras
item.description: They've long been man's best friend, but now dogs with one British police force can hound criminals in a new way thanks to "FidoCam," a digital video camera that straps to the canine's head.

item.title: Happy birthday, Nelson Mandela
item.description: South Africans celebrated Nelson Mandela's 94th birthday Wednesday by participating in good deeds nationwide to honor the legacy of the famous statesman.

item.title: Beating China's one-child policy
item.description: Something isn't quite right with this picture. There seem to be too many children here. Isn't this the country famed for its one-child policy? Aren't their big fines and penalties for having that second child?

item.title: Spain's royal pay cut
item.description: CNN's Erin Burnett talks about Spain monarchy's willingness to take a pay cut in Tuesdays the Number.

item.title: Quiz: Could you park a plane?
item.description: Every day 1,300 aircraft pass through London's Heathrow Airport. Making sure all those planes are in the right place at the right time is the job of the aircraft marshal.

item.title: Writer's week living at Heathrow
item.description: Heathrow Airport is under close scrutiny over how it will cope with the influx of travelers for the London Olympics, but at least it has one fan in British writer Tony Parsons.

item.title: Heathrow ready for the Olympics?
item.description: Becky Anderson visits Heathrow's multi-million dollar Games Terminal that will host 80% of travel during the Olympics

item.title: Inside a tense prisoner exchange
item.description: Local diplomacy wins the day in one small corner of Syria as a prisoner exchange turns into a Middle Eastern family sitcom.

item.title: With the rebels: Guns, mortars and mansions
item.description: A distant machine gun rattled away in vain as a military helicopter flew long, slow circles, arcing from the contested Syrian city of Aleppo over to the rebel-controlled town of Anadan, six miles to the north.

item.title: The 'Street of Death'
item.description: CNN's Ivan Watson finds that fighting in one Syrian town has left rubble, stunned survivors and not much else. Its main street is now known as "the street of death."

item.title: Scrambling to save kids
item.description: Filmmaker, Marcel Mettelsiefen documents the carnage wrought on Rastan by the Syrian Army's relentless shelling.

item.title: Photos: Olympics get under way
item.description: Photos: Olympics get under way

item.title: Why gritty East End is London's gold standard
item.description: For visitors and newcomers, the mention of London conjures up images of the queen, gray skies, Big Ben and Parliament.

item.title: Russian adoption outrage
item.description: Americans are afraid of an adoption treaty with Russia that may allow Russians into their homes. Kyung Lah reports.

item.title: Syrian rebels: From rocks to RPGs
item.description: The rebels have gone from being a ragtag defense force to an armed movement capable of attacking big cities, but they have been vastly outgunned. That may be changing.

item.title: Worst blackout in a decade hits India
item.description: A grid failure cut power supplies in northern India on Monday, hitting rail and road transport for hours in the country's worst blackout in a decade, authorities said.

item.title: Flood dream spurs 'Johan's Ark'
item.description: A Dutchman has built a replica of Noah's Ark to biblical proportions, following a dream his homeland would be flooded.

item.title: 2 U.S. climbers found dead in Peru
item.description: The bodies of two American climbers were discovered Saturday afternoon in the mountains of Peru, ending a days-long search for the men, friends and family said.

item.title: Spa offers 'snake massage'
item.description: A Moscow spa uses snakes as part of its exotic massage service.

item.title: Who'll win swimming, gymnastics medals on Monday?
item.description: The Olympic pool will be a focal point of more drama Monday, with four gold medals to be awarded at the Aquatics Center.

item.title: Worst power outage in a decade hits India
item.description: A grid failure cut power supplies in northern India on Monday, hitting rail and road transport for hours in the country's worst blackout in a decade, authorities said.

item.title: Train fire in India kills dozens
item.description: A fire swept through a passenger car of a train in southern India on Monday, killing at least 27 people, the authorities said. They cautioned that the death toll could rise further.

item.title: Russian band Pussy Riot pleads not guilty to hooliganism
item.description: Three members of the Russian punk rock band Pussy Riot pleaded not guilty Monday to charges of hooliganism after performing a song criticizing President Vladimir Putin in a Moscow church, Russia's state news agency reported.

item.title: Report: Mexican newspaper office set on fire
item.description: Two masked men set the offices of a prominent Mexican newspaper on fire Sunday, the second such attack on the daily this month.

item.title: Panetta kicks off tour to the Middle East
item.description: Defense Secretary Leon Panetta arrived in Tunisia late Sunday for the first leg of a five-day, four-nation trip to North Africa and the Middle East.

item.title: North Korea floods kill dozens
item.description: Heavy rain across large swathes of North Korea has caused widespread flooding and killed dozens of people, state media reported, with warnings of more damage still to come.

item.title: An Olympian without a country
item.description: Even though he will not compete in the London Olympics under his country's flag, South Sudan native Guor Marial basks with pride as the first athlete from the world's youngest nation in the global arena.

item.title: Munich widow pleas for silence
item.description: The widow of an Israeli Olympian killed in a terrorist attack on the 1972 Munich Games made an urgent plea Wednesday for a minute of silence at the opening ceremony to remember her husband and 10 other Israelis murdered 40 years ago.

item.title: British etiquette: Do's and don'ts
item.description: CNN's Becky Anderson gives advice on the do's and don'ts for visitors to London during the Olympic Games.

item.title: Reporter arrested in UK hacking
item.description: A journalist at Rupert Murdoch's British tabloid newspaper The Sun was arrested Monday on suspicion of culling information from stolen cell phones.

item.title: Romania president: Impeachment fails
item.description: The fate of Romanian President Traian Basescu will be determined Sunday, as the country votes on a referendum to impeach him.

item.title: Who was Bulgaria suicide bomber?
item.description: Bulgarian police have widened their investigation into last week's bombing attack on Israeli tourists to towns near the border with Romania, asking hotels for surveillance video that might have captured the suspected bomber.

item.title: Assange's mom seeks Ecuador help
item.description: The mother of WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange will meet with Ecuadorian authorities Monday to urge them to grant her son asylum.

item.title: 2 Americans found dead in Peru
item.description: The bodies of two American climbers were discovered Saturday afternoon in the mountains of Peru, ending a days-long search for the men, friends and family said.

item.title: Quake strikes off Guatemala coast
item.description: A 6.0-magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of Guatemala near the country's border with Mexico Sunday morning, the U.S. Geological Survey said.

item.title: Militants clash with Iraq forces
item.description: Suspected al Qaeda militants clashed with Iraqi forces Thursday, in attacks that began two days after a wave of violence across Iraq.

item.title: Arrests in nuke scientist death
item.description: Iran has arrested suspects in connection with the July 2011 killing of a nuclear scientist, semiofficial media reported, citing Intelligence Minister Heidar Moslehi.

item.title: Son Facebooked, dad arrested
item.description: How many young people have gotten in trouble for something they've posted on Facebook? Maybe a party picture or an offensive comment compromised their chances at a job. It happens all the time. But a 25-year-old Iranian says his Facebook activity has led to his father's detention in a notorious prison in Tehran. And now he's struggling to find a way to free him.

item.title: Kenyans win CNN journalism award
item.description: A story about an African tribe in India, long-forgotten and little-known, has garnered two Kenyan journalists the top prize at the CNN MultiChoice African Journalist 2012 Awards Ceremony.

item.title: Soldiers mutiny at army base
item.description: Two people were killed and one wounded in an apparent mutiny by soldiers at a base outside Madagascar's capital, Antananarivo, military authorities reported Sunday.

item.title: Kidnapped Olympic official released
item.description: The kidnapped president of the Libyan Olympic Committee was freed Sunday, a week after he was seized, the country's state news agency reported.

channel.title: CNN.com - U.S.
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - U.S.
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: No average person needs an AK 47
item.description: Roland Martin says the Constitution does not say you can have any gun you want. The president is right: AK 47's belong on the battlefield, not on city streets

item.title: Is it still too soon to talk gun control?
item.description: The horror in Aurora has faded from the front page but John Avlon says public officials have an obligation to pursue gun restrictions

item.title: Cheating is as old as the Olympics
item.description: David Potter says people have tried to get an unfair edge in the Olympics since ancient times

item.title: Technology makes us vulnerable
item.description: Marc Goodman says every advance in technology carries a risk that criminals and terrorists can exploit it

item.title: Opinion: Is 'Dear' dead?
item.description: Bob Greene says fewer people begin their emails with "Dear," opting instead for "Hi" or "Hey" in a sign of a new informality

item.title: Having kids making you less happy?
item.description: Amitai Etzioni says recent articles complaining that parenting detracts from happiness fail to consider that the deep mutuality of parenting makes us into fully rounded and better human beings

item.title: Phelps: 'I consider myself normal'
item.description: "I like to think of myself as a normal person who has a passion, has a goal and a dream and goes out and does it," Michael Phelps told Piers Morgan. "That's really how I've always lived my life."

item.title: Opinion: Chick-fil-A & free speech
item.description: First Amendment lawyer Marc Randazza says CEO Dan Cathy can state his views on same-sex marriage and politicians can condemn them -- but they can't give their own views the force of law

item.title: Changing child welfare system
item.description: These days, Marchelle Roberts is a confident 22-year-old who smiles easily and talks excitedly about her plans for the future.

item.title: Nuclear danger in California?
item.description: Activists fear a Southern California nuclear plant is the next Fukushima. CNN's Kyung Lah reports.

item.title: Meet Favre, high school coach
item.description: Watch as NFL great Brett Favre takes the field - as a high school football coach in Mississippi.

item.title: Nasty campaign ads flood your TV
item.description: Ken Goldstein, Ron Brownstein, & Michael Scherer analyze the ads of the 2012 presidential campaign cycle.

item.title: 3,000 miles on a skateboard?
item.description: Two childhood friends travel across the U.S. using a skateboard and a bike to raise earth awareness.

item.title: SUV plows through house
item.description: Neighhbors say the driver hit four cars before driving through the house. A woman sleeping inside the house was hurt.

item.title: Man climbs with no rope
item.description: Alex Honnold might be rock climbing's next big thing. The 26-year-old is capturing attention with his rope-free daredevil climbs.

item.title: Sparks fly between gun owners
item.description: When you put a pro- and an anti-gun control person in the same room, you know what's bound to happen. But what happens when two gun owners debate gun control?

item.title: Charities overvaluing donations?
item.description: Roy Tidwell's shipping business is in the middle of a debate over how charities put a monetary value on the items they donate. One charity claimed it sent $816,000 worth of medicines to an elephant charity in Nepal. But the customs declaration showed that its total stated value was actually $2,500.

item.title: Survivors face medical bills
item.description: CNN's Ed Lavandera reports on the costly treatments and operations needed by gunshot victims who survived the shooting.

item.title: The three who gave their lives
item.description: William Bennett says in Jon Blunk, Alex Teves and Matt McGuinn shielded their girlfriends from shooter, sacrificing their lives for a code of honor

item.title: Help for the victims
item.description: Aurora, Colorado, is a city in mourning after a gunman opened fire in a crowded movie theater, killing at least 12 and injuring 58. For anyone wanting to extend their sympathy and words of support for those impacted by the massacre, there are several ways to help.

item.title: Brain condition helps save life
item.description: Call it what you will -- providence, fate or simply a stroke of incredibly good luck -- Colorado shooting victim Petra Anderson has some of it.

item.title: Comforting grieving parents
item.description: Of the 12 people killed in last week's mass shooting at a Colorado movie theater, 6-year-old Veronica Moser-Sullivan was the youngest. Her mother, Ashley Moser, remained hospitalized Tuesday for injuries suffered during the shooting.

item.title: Newborn 'a silver lining'
item.description: A few reflections from survivors of the massacre at an Aurora, Colorado, theater from CNN interviews:

item.title: Tales of heroism abound
item.description: Even as a masked gunman kept firing a hailstorm of bullets in a Colorado movie theater, acts of selflessness and heroism sprouted from all across the room.

item.title: Hero saved friend from dying
item.description: Seconds after a gunman shot Allie Young in the neck in a crowded Colorado theater, a friend, Stephanie Davis, pulled her into an aisle, put pressure on her wound and dialed 911. Young told her friend to run, but Davies refused.

item.title: Photos: Mourning the victims
item.description: Photos: Mourning the victims of the Colorado massacre

item.title: Colorado shooting suspect in court
item.description: The man accused of opening fire inside an Aurora, Colorado, movie theater is expected to return to court Monday where he will face formal charges.

item.title: Grieving dad: Remember the humanity
item.description: It is the goodness of humanity that Tom Teves wants the world to know and remember: the virtues of his son Alex -- and the 11 others killed in a movie theater in Aurora, Colorado, on July 20.

item.title: Nuclear danger in California?
item.description: Activists fear a Southern California nuclear plant is the next Fukushima. CNN's Kyung Lah reports.

item.title: Driver peels out on cops
item.description: A witness captured video of a hit-and-run suspect driving off as police attempt to smash his windows.

item.title: Murder trial of Drew Peterson to kick off with opening statements
item.description: Eight and a half years after his third wife was found dead in a bathtub, the murder trial of former Chicago-area police officer Drew Peterson is set to begin in earnest with opening statements Tuesday.

item.title: Democrats propose limits on online ammo sales
item.description: Two Democratic lawmakers took on the hot-button political issue of gun control Monday, introducing legislation that would effectively ban online ammunition sales.

item.title: Aurora shooting suspect charged with murder
item.description: Colorado movie shooting suspect James Holmes was charged Monday with 24 counts of first-degree murder -- two counts for each of the 12 people killed in the shooting. Twelve murder counts cite "deliberation," and 12 cite "extreme indifference" to the value of human life.

item.title: NFL player kills himself at his former high school
item.description: O.J. Murdock, who signed with the NFL's Tennessee Titans last year, killed himself Monday morning in front of the Tampa, Florida, high school where he was a track and football star, police said.

item.title: Man injured off Massachusetts shore; authorities suspect shark bite
item.description: A man who suffered lacerations to his legs while in the water at a Massachusetts beach Monday apparently was bitten by a shark, authorities said.

item.title: Gas prices up after long skid
item.description: U.S. gasoline prices have gone up by nearly a dime a gallon in the past two weeks, reversing a wallet-pleasin' three-month slide.

item.title: Zimmerman's wife pleads not guilty on perjury charge
item.description: The wife of George Zimmerman has pleaded not guilty to a perjury charge related to allegedly lying about the family's finances as her husband faced murder charges in the death of unarmed teenager Trayvon Martin, a court official said.

item.title: What's on tap for Monday
item.description: The Olympic pool will be a focal point of more drama Monday, with four gold medals to be awarded at the Aquatics Center.

item.title: Day 3: The best photos of the Olympics
item.description: Day 3: The best photos of the Olympics
